<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	royalty payments to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Mr.&nbsp;Myoung-Jin
</FONT>
	Lee for the right to use the
	storyline and characters from his &#147;Ragnarok&#148; cartoon series used in our games and other products based on Ragnarok. We paid Mr.&nbsp;Lee an initial license fee of Won&nbsp;40&nbsp;million and are required to pay royalties based on 1.0% or
	1.5% of adjusted revenues (net of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	value-added
</FONT>
	taxes and certain other expenses) or 2.5%, 5% or 10% of net income generated from the use of the Ragnarok brand, depending on the type of revenues received from
	the operation or licensing of Ragnarok Online.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The cost of revenues from the payments to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Mr.&nbsp;Myoung-Jin
</FONT>
	Lee was Won&nbsp;197&nbsp;million (US$168&nbsp;thousand) for 2015 and Won&nbsp;185&nbsp;million for 2014. This agreement expires in January 2033.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	64
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage65"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D64640D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Selling, general and administrative expenses
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Selling, general and administrative expenses consist of sales commissions paid to independent promotional agents that
	distribute our online games to our Internet caf&eacute; subscribers in Korea, commissions paid to payment settlement providers, administrative expenses and related personnel expenses of executive and administrative staff, and marketing and
	promotional expenses and related personnel expenses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Research and development expenses
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Research and development expenses consist primarily of payroll and other overhead expenses which are all expensed as incurred
	(i)&nbsp;until technological feasibility of an online game is reached or (ii)&nbsp;until commercial operation of a mobile game commences. Once technological feasibility of an online game is reached, these costs are capitalized and, once commercial
	operation commences, amortized as cost of revenues. See ITEM&nbsp;5.A. &#147;OPERATING RESULTS&#151;CRITICAL ACCOUNTING POLICIES&#151;Capitalized software development costs.&#148;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Foreign currency effects
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In 2015, 49.0% of our revenues were denominated in foreign currencies, primarily in U.S.&nbsp;dollar and Japanese Yen.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In most of the countries in which our games are distributed, the revenues generated by our overseas subsidiaries and licensees
	are denominated in local currencies, which include Japanese Yen, Euro, NT dollar, Thai Baht and Chinese Yuan. The revenues from those countries, other than the United States, Japan and European countries, are converted into the U.S.&nbsp;dollar for
	remittance of monthly royalty payments to us. Depreciation of these local currencies against the U.S.&nbsp;dollar will result in reduced monthly royalty payments in U.S.&nbsp;dollar terms, thereby having a negative impact on our net income.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Although we receive our monthly royalty revenues from our overseas licensees in foreign currencies, primarily in Japanese Yen
	and U.S.&nbsp;dollar, and other local currencies, such as NT dollar and Thai Baht in our other principal markets, substantially all of our costs are denominated in Won. We receive monthly royalty payments from our overseas licensees based on an
	agreed percentage of revenues confirmed and recorded at the end of each month applying the foreign exchange rate applicable on such date. We generally receive these royalty payments 20 to 30&nbsp;days after the end of each month unless delayed due
	to extraordinary circumstances. Appreciation or depreciation of the Won against these foreign currencies during this period will result in foreign currency losses or gains and affect our net income.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, we had no foreign currency forward contract outstanding. See ITEM&nbsp;11.
	&#147;QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE DISCLOSURES ABOUT MARKET RISK&#151;Foreign currency risk.&#148;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Income tax expenses
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	See ITEM&nbsp;3.D. &#147;RISK FACTORS&#151;RISKS RELATING TO OUR BUSINESS&#151;Adverse changes in the withholding tax rates in
	the countries from which we receive license fees and royalties could adversely affect our net income.&#148; and ITEM&nbsp;5.A. &#147;OPERATING RESULTS&#151;CRITICAL ACCOUNTING POLICIES&#151;Income taxes.&#148;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	CRITICAL ACCOUNTING POLICIES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Our discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations are based upon our financial statements, which
	have been prepared in accordance with U.S.&nbsp;GAAP. The preparation of these financial statements requires us to make estimates, judgments and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities, contingent liabilities, and
	revenue and expenses during the reporting period. We evaluate our estimates on an ongoing basis based on historical experience and other assumptions we believe are reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making
	judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	65
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage66"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D64640D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	other sources. The policies discussed below are considered by our management to be critical because they are not only important to the portrayal of our financial condition and results of
	operations but also because the application and interpretation of these policies require both judgment and estimates of matters that are inherently uncertain and unknown. As a result, actual results may differ materially from our estimates.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Revenue recognition
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We derive, and expect to continue to generate, most of our revenues from online game subscription revenue generated in the
	countries where our games are offered by us, royalties and license fees paid by our licensees in overseas markets, and mobile games and applications revenue. Our revenues can be classified into the following four categories: (i)&nbsp;online
	games&#151;subscription revenue; (ii)&nbsp;online games&#151;royalties and license fees; (iii)&nbsp;mobile games and applications revenue; and (iv)&nbsp;character merchandising, animation and other revenue. For details, see ITEM&nbsp;5.A.
	&#147;OPERATING RESULTS&#151;OVERVIEW&#151;Revenues.&#148;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We recognize revenue in accordance with U.S.&nbsp;GAAP, as set
	forth in Accounting Standards Codification, or ASC 605,
<I>
	Revenue Recognition
</I>
	and other related pronouncements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Allowances for
	doubtful accounts
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We maintain allowances for doubtful accounts receivable for estimated losses that result from the
	inability of our customers to make the required payments. We base our allowances on the likelihood of recoverability of accounts receivable based on past experience and current collection trends. We record allowances for doubtful accounts based on
	historical payment patterns of our customers and increase our allowances as the length of time such receivables become past due increases.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Subsequent to June 2003, pursuant to agreements with various payment processing service providers, the providers are
	responsible for remitting to us the full subscription revenues generated in Korea after deducting their fixed service fees and charges of approximately 1.4% to 15%. In addition, we do not assume any collection risk since payment processing service
	providers now bear the risk of loss and delinquency.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Capitalized software development costs
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We capitalize certain software development costs relating to online games that will be distributed through subscriptions or
	licenses. The Company accounts for software development costs in accordance with ASC 985, Costs of Software to be Sold, Leased, or Marketed. Software development costs incurred prior to the establishment of technological feasibility are expensed
	when incurred and are included in research and development expense. We establish technological feasibility of a product when closed beta testing has been completed and open best testing has started. Once a software product has reached technological
	feasibility, then all subsequent software development costs for that product are capitalized until the product is commercially launched. Technological feasibility is evaluated on a product by product basis, but typically occurs when the online game
	has a proven ability to operate on a multiplayer level for a large number of users. Technological feasibility of a product encompasses both technical design documentation and game design documentation.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We evaluate the recoverability of capitalized software development costs on a product by product basis. The recoverability of
	capitalized software development costs is evaluated based on the expected performance of the specific products to which the costs relate. Criteria used to evaluate expected product performance include: historical performance of comparable products
	using comparable technology; orders for the product prior to its release; and estimated performance of a sequel product based on the performance of the product on which the sequel is based. Capitalized costs for those products that are cancelled are
	expensed in the period of cancellation. In addition, an impairment loss shall be recorded when management&#146;s forecast for a particular game indicates that unamortized capitalized costs exceed the net realizable value of that asset. Significant
	management judgments and estimates are utilized in the
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	66
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage67"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D64640D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	assessment of when technological feasibility is established, as well as in the ongoing assessment of the recoverability of capitalized costs. In evaluating the recoverability of capitalized
	costs, the assessment of expected product performance utilizes forecasted sales amounts and estimates of additional development costs to be incurred. If revised forecasted or actual product sales are changed from the original forecasted amounts
	utilized in the initial recoverability analysis, the actual impairment charge may be larger than originally estimated in any given period.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Significant management judgment is required to assess the timing of technological feasibility as well as the ongoing
	recoverability of capitalized costs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Impairment of goodwill and other intangible assets
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Goodwill represents the excess of the purchase price over the fair value of the identifiable net assets acquired in a business
	combination.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Goodwill is accounted for under ASC 350,
<I>
	Intangibles&#151;Goodwill and Other
</I>
	, which requires that
	goodwill and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	indefinite-lived
</FONT>
	intangible assets are not amortized, but instead be tested at least annually for impairment, and more frequently if an event occurs or circumstances change which would more likely
	than not reduce the fair value of these assets below their carrying amount. Such an event would include unfavorable variances from established business plans, significant changes in forecasted results or volatility inherent to external markets and
	industries, which are periodically reviewed by our management. Specifically, qualitative factors are assessed to determine whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount, including
	goodwill. In evaluating whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount, the relevant events and circumstances are assessed. If, after assessing the totality of events or circumstances, it
	is determined that it is not more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount, then a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	two-step
</FONT>
	process of the goodwill impairment test is not performed.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	If it is determined that it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount,
	then the first step of the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	two-step
</FONT>
	goodwill impairment test is performed. The first step of the goodwill impairment test is used to identify potential impairment by comparing the fair value of a reporting
	unit with its carrying amount, including goodwill. If the carrying amount of a reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the second step of the goodwill impairment test is performed to measure the amount of impairment loss, if any. The second step of
	the goodwill impairment test compares the implied fair value of the reporting unit&#146;s goodwill with the carrying amount of that goodwill. If the carrying amount of the reporting unit&#146;s goodwill exceeds the implied fair value of that
	goodwill, an impairment loss is recognized immediately in an amount equal to that excess. The goodwill impairment test is carried out at the reporting unit, which is either an operating division or a subdivision, for which
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	stand-alone
</FONT>
	financial information is available to the management personnel of such division or subdivision for evaluating operating results.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We performed our annual impairment test for goodwill at our reporting unit using data as of December&nbsp;31, 2013, 2014 and
	2015. In performing the valuations, we used cash flows, which reflected management&#146;s forecasts and discount rates which reflect the risks associated with the current market. Prior to performing the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	two-step
</FONT>
	impairment test for goodwill, we performed a qualitative assessment for the reporting unit.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In 2014, we concluded not to recognize impairment loss for goodwill as the fair value of the business reporting unit was
	determined to be greater than its carrying amount.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In 2015, we recorded impairment losses of Won 1,210&nbsp;million in the
	reporting unit NeoCyon, as a result of the goodwill impairment test. The fair value of the reporting unit was estimated principally using the expected present value of the future cash flows. Due to a decline in forecasted performance in our annual
	goodwill impairment test, the fair value of the reporting unit NeoCyon was determined to be lower than its carrying amount.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	67
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage68"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D64640D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In performing the annual impairment test for goodwill for Gravity Games in 2013,
	the fair value of the business reporting unit Gravity Games was determined to be lower than its carrying amount. Therefore, during the fiscal year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, we recorded impairment losses of
<STRIKE>
	W
</STRIKE>
	2,653&nbsp;million in
	the reporting unit of Gravity Games due to the overall decline in the fair value of the reporting unit and uncertainty regarding the future. The fair value of the reporting unit was estimated principally using the expected present value of the
	future cash flows. As a result of such impairment, the goodwill for the reporting unit of Gravity Games Corporation was fully written off as of December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Product technology, presented as an acquired intangible asset in balance sheets, represents product technology related to
	Dragonica which was recognized as a result of a business combination with Gravity Games in 2010 and illustrated images purchased from a third party in 2014. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the carrying value of such product technology are nil and Won
	23&nbsp;million, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Product technology is accounted for under ASC 350,
<I>
	Intangibles&#151;Goodwill and
	Other
</I>
	, which requires that intangible assets subject to amortization shall be reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of the asset or asset group may not be recoverable in accordance
	with ASC 360,
<I>
	Property, Plant and Equipment
</I>
	. An impairment loss shall be recognized if the carrying amount of an intangible asset is not recoverable and its carrying amount exceeds its fair value. The carrying value is considered
	unrecoverable if it exceeds the sum of the undiscounted cash flows anticipated from the use and eventual disposition of the asset. Impairment loss is measured as the amount by which the carrying value of an asset exceeds its fair value.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As a significant decrease in revenue of Dragonica was noted in 2013, which was a trigger event for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	long-lived
</FONT>
	assets impairment analysis as of December&nbsp;31, 2013, we performed an impairment test on Dragonica. As the carrying amount of Dragonica exceeded its fair value, we recognized an impairment loss of
	Won&nbsp;1,424&nbsp;million for Dragonica in 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The assessment of impairments under ASC 350 and ASC 360 requires
	significant judgment and requires estimates to assess fair values. We believe that the estimates of future cash flows and fair value used in the impairment tests of goodwill and product technology are reasonable. However, in the future, changes in
	estimates resulting in lower than currently anticipated cash flows and fair value due to unforeseen changes in business assumptions could negatively affect the valuations, which may result in us recognizing impairment charges for goodwill and other
	intangible assets in the future.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Income taxes
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We account for income taxes under the provisions of ASC 740,
<I>
	Income Taxes
</I>
	. Under ASC 740, income taxes are accounted for
	under the asset and liability method.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Management judgment is required in determining our provision for income taxes,
	deferred tax assets and liabilities, and the extent to which deferred tax assets can be realized. A valuation allowance is provided for deferred tax assets to the extent that it is more likely than not that such deferred tax assets will not be
	realized. Realization of future tax benefits related to the deferred tax assets is dependent on many factors, including our ability to generate taxable income within the period during which the temporary differences reverse, the outlook for the
	economic environment in which the business operates and the overall future industry outlook. In 2014 and 2015, we concluded that it was more likely than not that deferred tax assets of Gravity and its subsidiaries could not be realized in the near
	future based on our historical and projected net and taxable income. As a result, we recognized full allowance from deferred tax assets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Segment Reporting
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	An operating segment is defined as a component of a company that engages in business activities for which discrete financial
	information is available and that is regularly reviewed by the company&#146;s Chief Operating Decision Maker (the &#147;CODM&#148;) to make decisions about resources to be allocated to the
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	68
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage69"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D64640D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	segment and assess its performance. In accordance with ASC 280,
<I>
	Segment Reporting
</I>
	, the Company currently operates and manages its business as several operating and reportable segments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Our operating segments are consistent with our internal organizational structure, the manner in which our operations are
	reviewed and managed by our Chief Executive Officer, who is our CODM, the manner in which we assess operating performance and allocate resources, and the availability of separate financial information.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We had previously reported our results of operations under one operating segment. In 2015, we realigned new operating segments
	comprised of online game operations and mobile game operations. During the fiscal year of 2015, our CODM decided to begin to receive and analyze separate financial information of the operating segments in order to perform independent evaluations
	about our online game operations and mobile game operations and to make separate business decisions and, also to allocate resources for each segment. The nature of change is based on our consideration about (i)&nbsp;recent focus on mobile game
	business due to significant growth of global mobile game market as well as (ii)&nbsp;gradually declining portion of our online game revenues in our total revenues.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Our CODM does not review any information regarding total assets on an operating segment basis, and accordingly, no disclosure
	is made with respect thereto. Information on the operating segments and reconciliations of total net revenues and total segment operating income to consolidated net revenues from external customers and consolidated operating income for the years
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, 2014, and 2015 are presented in the table below.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Recent accounting pronouncements
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In July 2013, the FASB issued ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2013-11,
</FONT>
	Income Taxes, which requires the
	presentation of certain unrecognized tax benefits as reductions to deferred tax assets rather than as liabilities in the Consolidated Balance Sheets when a net operating loss carryforward, a similar tax loss, or a tax credit carryforward exists. The
	new standard requires adoption on a prospective basis in the first quarter of 2015. The adoptions of ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2013-05
</FONT>
	did not have a material impact on our consolidated financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In May 2014, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) issued ASU 2014-09,
<I>
	Revenue from Contracts with Customers
</I>
	.
	ASU 2014-09 supersedes the revenue recognition requirements in &#147;Revenue Recognition (Topic 605)&#148;, and requires entities to recognize revenue when it transfers promised goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the
	consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled to in exchange for those goods or services. As currently issued and amended, ASU 2014-09 is
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	69
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage70"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D64640D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2017, including interim periods within that reporting period, though early adoption is permitted for annual reporting
	periods beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2016. This guidance will be effective beginning January&nbsp;1, 2018 and can be applied either retrospectively to each period presented or as a cumulative-effect adjustment as of the date of adoption. We are
	currently evaluating the adoption method as well as the impact of this new accounting guidance on our consolidated financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In August 2014, the FASB issued ASU 2014-15, Presentation of Financial Statements-Going Concern, which provides guidance on
	determining when and how reporting entities must disclose going-concern uncertainties in their financial statements. The new standard requires management to perform interim and annual assessments of an entity&#146;s ability to continue as a going
	concern within one year of the date of issuance of the entity&#146;s financial statements (or within one year after the date on which the financial statements are available to be issued, when applicable). Further, an entity must provide certain
	disclosures if there is &#147;substantial doubt about the entity&#146;s ability to continue as a going concern.&#148; The ASU is effective for annual periods ending after December&nbsp;15, 2016, and interim periods thereafter. Early adoption is
	permitted. The ASU shall be applied at the effective date, and we are in the process of evaluating the impact of the standard on its consolidated financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In February 2015, the FASB issued ASU 2015-02,
<I>
	Consolidation (Topic 810): Amendments to the Consolidation Analysis
</I>
	,
	which changes the analysis that a reporting entity must perform to determine whether it should consolidate certain types of legal entities. We do not expect the adoption of this standard to have a material impact on our consolidated statement of
	operations or consolidated balance sheet, but it may result in additional disclosures.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In November 2015, the FASB issued
	ASU 2015-17,
<I>
	Balance Sheet Classification of Deferred Taxes
</I>
	, an amended standard, requiring that we classify all deferred tax assets and liabilities as non-current on the balance sheet instead of separating deferred taxes into current and
	non-current. The amended standard is effective for us beginning in the first quarter of 2017; early adoption is permitted and we are evaluating whether we will early adopt. The amended standard may be adopted on either a prospective or retrospective
	basis. We do not expect that the adoption of this standard will have a significant impact on our financial position or results of operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In January 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-01,
<I>
	Financial Instruments-Overall
</I>
	, which changes the accounting for financial
	instruments that primarily affect equity investments, financial liabilities under the fair value option, and the presentation and disclosure requirements for financial instruments. This standard is effective for us beginning in the first quarter of
	2018; certain provisions allow for early adoption and we are evaluating whether we will elect to early adopt these provisions. The new standard should be applied by means of a cumulative-effect adjustment to the balance sheet as of the beginning of
	the fiscal year of adoption, with certain exceptions. We do not expect that the adoption of this standard will have a significant impact on our financial position or results of operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In February 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-02,
<I>
	Leases
</I>
	, which provides guidance for lease accounting. The new guidance
	contained in the ASU stipulates that lessees will need to recognize a right-of-use asset and a lease liability for substantially all leases (other than leases that meet the definition of a short-term lease). The liability will be equal to the
	present value of lease payments. Treatment in the consolidated statements of comprehensive loss will be similar to the current treatment of operating and capital leases. This standard will be effective for annual reporting periods (including interim
	reporting period within those periods) beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2018. We are in the process of evaluating the impact of the standard on its consolidated financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	70
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<I>
	Notes:
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:4PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	For convenience only, the Won amounts are expressed in U.S.&nbsp;dollars at the rate of Won&nbsp;1,169.26 to
	US$1.00, the noon buying rate in effect on December&nbsp;31, 2015 as certified by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for customs purposes.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	71
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage72"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D64640D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	Gross profit margin for each period is calculated by dividing gross profit by total net revenue for each
	period.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(3)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	Operating profit margin for each period is calculated by dividing operating loss by total net revenue for each
	period.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(4)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	Represents the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-controlling
</FONT>
	interest in NeoCyon, a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	96.1%-
</FONT>
	held subsidiary acquired in December 2005, and Gravity Games, a subsidiary acquired in October 2010, in which our initial ownership was 50.8% and which increased to 85.5% in August 2013
<I>
	.
</I>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Revenues
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Our total revenues decreased by 10.6% to Won&nbsp;35,660&nbsp;million (US$30,497&nbsp;thousand) in 2015 from
	Won&nbsp;39,889&nbsp;million in 2014, primarily due to:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	a 15.9% decrease in royalties and license fees to Won&nbsp;11,010&nbsp;million (US$9,416&nbsp;thousand) in
	2015 from Won&nbsp;13,093&nbsp;million in 2014, which was due mainly to decreased revenues from Ragnarok Online in Japan resulting from increasing competition and decreasing Ragnarok Online game users due to the relative maturity of such game, and
	the strengthening of the Korean Won by approximately 5.3% against the Japanese Yen from 2014 to 2015;
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	a 18.1% decrease in subscription revenue to Won&nbsp;6,521&nbsp;million (US$5,577&nbsp;thousand) in 2015 from
	Won&nbsp;7,962&nbsp;million in 2014, resulting primarily from decreased revenues from Ragnarok Online II in the United States/Canada and Taiwan resulting from increasing competition and weak demand for the game, though such decrease was partially
	offset by an increase in revenues from Ragnarok Online in Korea; and
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	a 19.3% decrease in character merchandising, animation and other revenue to Won 3,051&nbsp;million (US$2,609
	thousand) in 2015 from Won 3,779&nbsp;million in 2014, which was mainly attributable to decreased revenues from NeoCyon&#146;s web site development and operation services for third parties.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Such decreases were partially offset by:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	a 0.2% increase in mobile games and applications revenue to Won 15,078&nbsp;million (US$12,895&nbsp;thousand)
	in 2015 from Won 15,055&nbsp;million in 2014, which was mainly driven by revenue from mobile applications provided to third party enterprises.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Cost of revenues
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Our cost of revenues decreased by 11.4% to Won&nbsp;30,282&nbsp;million (US$25,898&nbsp;thousand) in 2015 from
	Won&nbsp;34,188&nbsp;million in 2014, primarily due to:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	a 10.7% decrease in salaries to Won&nbsp;10,163&nbsp;million (US$8,692&nbsp;thousand) in 2015 from
	Won&nbsp;11,378&nbsp;million in 2014 primarily resulting from a decrease in the number of employees;
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	a 60.8% decrease in depreciation expenses to Won&nbsp;484&nbsp;million (US$414&nbsp;thousand) in 2015 from
	Won&nbsp;1,234&nbsp;million in 2014, which was mostly related to the completed depreciation of the MS software license for game servers; and
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	a 20.5% decrease in outsourcing fees to Won&nbsp;2,731&nbsp;million (US$2,336&nbsp;thousand) in 2015 from
	Won&nbsp;3,435 million in 2014 primarily resulting from a decrease in outsourcing fees for NeoCyon&#146;s web site development and operation service for third parties.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Gross profit and gross profit margin
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As a result of the foregoing, our gross profit decreased by 5.7% to Won&nbsp;5,378&nbsp;million (US$ 4,599&nbsp;thousand) in
	2015 from Won&nbsp;5,701&nbsp;million in 2014. Our gross profit margin increased to 15.1&nbsp;% in 2015 from 14.3% in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	72
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage73"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D64640D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Operating expenses
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<I>
	Selling, general and administrative expenses.
</I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our selling, general and administrative expenses
	decreased by 9.5% to Won&nbsp;11,481&nbsp;million (US$9,819&nbsp;thousand) in 2015 from Won&nbsp;12,682&nbsp;million in 2014, primarily due to:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	a 13.7% decrease in salaries to Won&nbsp;4,086&nbsp;million (US$3,495&nbsp;thousand) in 2015 from
	Won&nbsp;4,735&nbsp;million in 2014 mostly attributable to a decrease in salaries as a result of a decrease in the number of employees; and
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	a 6.8% decrease in commission paid to Won&nbsp;2,938&nbsp;million (US$2,513&nbsp;thousand) in 2015 from
	Won&nbsp;3,152&nbsp;million in 2014 mostly attributable to a decrease in the registration fee of a trademark.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<I>
	Research and development expenses.
</I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our research and development expenses increased by 8.9% to
	Won&nbsp;5,277&nbsp;million (US$4,513&nbsp;thousand) in 2015 from Won&nbsp;4,847&nbsp;million in 2014 mainly due to increases in development expenses for mobile games.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<I>
	Impairment loss on intangible assets.
</I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We had Won 5,849&nbsp;million (US$5,002 thousand) in
	impairment losses on intangible assets in 2015, which mostly consisted of impairment losses for capitalized research and development cost of Ragnarok Online II and goodwill of NeoCyon, compared to impairment losses on intangible assets of Won
	1&nbsp;million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<I>
	Refund of initial payments received
</I>
	.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Ragnarok Online II license
	agreement in Japan with GungHo was terminated on February&nbsp;12, 2016. As part of the termination, US$5,000 thousand in initial payments received from GungHo will be refunded in four equal payments by the end of December 2017.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Operating loss and operating profit margin
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As a result of the cumulative effects of the reasons stated above, we recorded an operating loss of
	Won&nbsp;17,229&nbsp;million (US$14,735&nbsp;thousand) in 2015, compared to an operating loss of Won&nbsp;11,829&nbsp;million in 2014, and our operating profit margin was negative 48.3% in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Net other income
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Our net other income increased by 58.8% to Won&nbsp;1,551&nbsp;million (US$1,327&nbsp;thousand) in 2015 from
	Won&nbsp;977&nbsp;million in 2014 primarily due to other income related to the liquidation of Gravity Middle East&nbsp;&amp; Africa FZ LLC in 2015. As a result of the liquidation, the entire accumulated other comprehensive income balance of Won
	624&nbsp;million relating to Gravity Middle East&nbsp;&amp; Africa FZ LLC was reclassified to other income.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Income tax expenses
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We recorded an income tax expense of Won&nbsp;1,351&nbsp;million (US$1,155&nbsp;thousand) in 2015, compared to an
	income tax expense of Won&nbsp;10,147&nbsp;million in 2014 primarily due to recognizing the full valuation on allowances from deferred tax assets of Gravity and NeoCyon in 2014. In assessing the realizability of deferred tax assets, we considered
	whether it was more likely than not some portion or all of the deferred tax assets would not be realized. In 2014, we recorded a full valuation allowance on deferred tax assets of Gravity and NeoCyon, as we determined that it was more likely than
	not that none of the deferred tax assets were realizable in the near future.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-controlling
</FONT>
	interest
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-controlling
</FONT>
	interest represents the net loss from NeoCyon, our
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	96.11%-held
</FONT>
	subsidiary and Gravity Games, our
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	85.5%-held
</FONT>
	subsidiary, attributable to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	third-party
</FONT>
	minority interest holders. We acquired
	96.11% of the voting equity of NeoCyon in 2005. We acquired 50.83% of the voting equity of Gravity Games in 2010 and increased our ownership in Gravity Games to 85.5% in August 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	73
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage74"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D64640D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Net loss attributable to parent company
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As a result of the foregoing, we recorded a net loss attributable to parent company of Won&nbsp;16,965&nbsp;million
	(US$14,508&nbsp;thousand) in 2015 compared to a net loss attributable to parent company of Won&nbsp;20,907&nbsp;million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Segment Results
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Our net revenue from online game operations, prior to adjusting for inter-segment transactions, was Won 18,147&nbsp;million
	(US$15,520 thousand) in 2015, which was a 18.1% decrease from Won&nbsp;22,153&nbsp;million in 2014. Such decrease was primarily due to (i)&nbsp;decreased revenues from Ragnarok Online in Japan and the strengthening of the Korean Won by approximately
	5.3% against the Japanese Yen from 2014 to 2015 and (ii)&nbsp;decreased revenues from Ragnarok Online
<I>
</I>
	II in the United States/Canada and Taiwan. Our net revenue from mobile game operations was Won 15,350&nbsp;million (US$13,128 thousand) in
	2015, which was a 1.9% decrease from Won 15,649&nbsp;million in 2014, mostly related to a decline in revenues from mobile games released in previous years.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Prior to adjusting for inter-segment transactions, we recorded an operating loss of Won 7,038&nbsp;million (US$6,019 thousand)
	from online game operations in 2015, which was an increase of 52.2% from Won&nbsp;4,625&nbsp;million in 2014, resulting mainly from an impairment loss for capitalized research and development cost of Ragnarok Online II. Also, our operating loss from
	mobile game operations was Won&nbsp;9,701&nbsp;million (US$8,297 thousand), which was an increase of 34.8% from Won 7,196&nbsp;million in 2014, mainly due to an increase in advertising expenses and research and development expenses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	74
</P>

</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:10.0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000;WIDTH:26%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<I>
	Notes:
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:4PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	The accompanying 2013 consolidated statement of operations includes certain
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	out-of-period
</FONT>
</FONT>
	adjustments primarily related to the understatement of revenues for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	in-game
</FONT>
	items of Won&nbsp;981&nbsp;million that were not properly deferred in fiscal
	year 2012. Management believes the impact of these items, both individually and in the aggregate, to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 and to prior years presented are not&nbsp;material.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	75
</P>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	Gross profit margin for each period is calculated by dividing gross profit by total net revenue for each
	period.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(3)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	Operating profit margin for each period is calculated by dividing operating loss by total net revenue for each
	period.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(4)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	Represents the loss from our 16.39% equity investment in Online Game Revolution Fund No.&nbsp;1 in 2013. These
	investments were accounted for using the equity method of accounting.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(5)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	Represents the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-controlling
</FONT>
	interest in NeoCyon, a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	96.11%-
</FONT>
	held subsidiary acquired in December 2005, and Gravity Games, a subsidiary acquired in October 2010, in which our initial ownership was 50.83% and which increased to 85.5% in August 2013.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Revenues
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Our total revenues decreased by 16.3% to Won&nbsp;39,889&nbsp;million in 2014 from Won&nbsp;47,685&nbsp;million in 2013,
	primarily due to:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	a 39.7% decrease in royalties and license fees to Won&nbsp;13,093&nbsp;million in 2014 from
	Won&nbsp;21,726&nbsp;million in 2013, which was due mainly to decreased revenues from Ragnarok Online in Japan and China resulting from increasing competition and decreasing Ragnarok Online game users due to the relative maturity of such game, and
	the strengthening of the Korean Won by approximately 12.5% against the Japanese Yen from 2013 to 2014; and
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	a 3% decrease in subscription revenue to Won&nbsp;7,962&nbsp;million in 2014 from Won&nbsp;8,206&nbsp;million
	in 2013, resulting primarily from decreased revenues from Ragnarok Online II in the United States and Canada resulting from increasing competition and weak demand for the game, though such decrease was partially offset by an increase in revenues
	from Ragnarok Online in Korea and revenues from Ragnarok Online II in Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau where the game was commercially released on June 2014.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Such decreases were offset by:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	a 16.3% increase in character merchandising, animation and other revenue to Won 3,779&nbsp;million in 2014
	from Won 3,249&nbsp;million in 2013, which was due mainly to the increased revenues from NeoCyon&#146;s web site development and operation service for third parties; and
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	a 3.8% increase in mobile games and applications revenue to Won&nbsp;15,055&nbsp;million in 2014 from
	Won&nbsp;14,504&nbsp;million in 2013, mostly driven by increased revenues from Ragnarok Online&#151;Uprising: Valkyrie which was launched in May 2012, Road to Dragon which was launched in Korea in January 2014 and Battle Ship which was launched in
	Korea in November 2013.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Cost of revenues
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Our cost of revenues decreased by 3.4% to Won&nbsp;34,188&nbsp;million in 2014 from Won&nbsp;35,399&nbsp;million in 2013,
	primarily due to:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	a 33.0% decrease in amortization expenses for intangible assets to Won 3,989&nbsp;million in 2014 from Won
	5,951&nbsp;million in 2013 which was mostly related to decreased amortization for Dragonica and Ragnarok Odyssey. Dragonica was amortized and fully impaired in December 2013 and Ragnarok Odyssey was fully amortized in January 2014; and
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	a 9.7% decrease in salaries to Won 11,378&nbsp;million in 2014 from Won 12,600&nbsp;million in 2013 primarily
	resulting from a decrease in the number of employees.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Such decreases were offset by:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	a 64.0% increase in outsourcing fees to Won 3,435&nbsp;million in 2014 from 2,095&nbsp;million in 2013, which
	is mostly related to NeoCyon&#146;s web site development and operation service for third parties; and
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D64640D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	a 13.7% increase in commissions paid to Won 9,436&nbsp;million in 2014 from Won 8,298&nbsp;million in 2013
	mainly due to an increase in payments to digital storefronts where our mobile games are offered and royalty payments related to the commercial launch of some of our games.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Gross profit and gross profit margin
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As a result of the foregoing, our gross profit decreased by 53.6% to Won&nbsp;5,701&nbsp;million in 2014 from
	Won&nbsp;12,286&nbsp;million in 2013. Our gross profit margin decreased to 14.3% in 2014 from 25.8% in 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Operating expenses
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<I>
	Selling, general and administrative expenses.
</I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our selling, general and administrative
	expenses decreased by 25.7% to Won&nbsp;12,682&nbsp;million in 2014 from Won&nbsp;17,063&nbsp;million in 2013, primarily due to:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	a 31.3% decrease in salaries to Won 4,735&nbsp;million in 2014 from Won 6,896&nbsp;million in 2013 mostly
	attributable to a decrease in salaries as a result of a decrease in the number of employees; and
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	a 43.4% decrease in advertising expenses to Won 1,614&nbsp;million in 2014 from Won 2,852&nbsp;million in 2013
	mostly attributable to a decrease in marketing expenses for mobile games.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<I>
	Research and development
	expenses.
</I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our research and development expenses decreased by 20.9% to Won&nbsp;4,847&nbsp;million in 2014 from Won&nbsp;6,131&nbsp;million in 2013 mainly due to development expenses for Ragnarok Odyssey Ace for the
	PlayStation Vita platform in 2013, which were not incurred in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<I>
	Impairment loss on intangible
	assets.
</I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Impairment losses on intangible assets decreased by 99.9% to Won 1&nbsp;million in 2014 from Won 5,822&nbsp;million in 2013. The impairment losses on intangible assets in 2013 mostly consisted of impairment losses
	for goodwill of Gravity Games, intangible assets of Dragonica, and capitalized research and development cost of Requiem Returns W, Ragnarok Odyssey Ace for the PlayStation Vita Platform, Steal Fighter, Game Station, which is a mobile game service
	platform, Maestia and Ragnarok Online Guild Masters, none of which were incurred in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Operating loss and operating profit margin
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As a result of the cumulative effects of the reasons stated above, we recorded an operating loss of
	Won&nbsp;11,829&nbsp;million in 2014, compared to an operating loss of Won&nbsp;16,730 million in 2013, and our operating profit margin was negative 29.7% in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Net other income
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Our net other income decreased 53.6% to Won&nbsp;977&nbsp;million in 2014 from Won&nbsp;2,105&nbsp;million in 2013 primarily
	due to other income related to the liquidation of Online Game Revolution Fund No.&nbsp;1 in 2013, as there was no similar liquidation in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Income tax expenses
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We recorded an income tax expense of Won&nbsp;10,147&nbsp;million in 2014, compared to an income tax expense of
	Won&nbsp;5,108&nbsp;million in 2013, mostly due to recognizing a full valuation on allowances from deferred tax assets of Gravity and NeoCyon in 2014. In assessing the realizability of deferred tax assets, we considered whether it was more likely
	than not some portion or all of the deferred tax assets would not be realized. In 2014, we recorded a full valuation allowance on deferred tax assets of Gravity and NeoCyon, as we determined that it was more likely than not that none of the deferred
	tax assets were realizable in the near future.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Equity loss on investments
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In 2013, equity loss on investments represents the losses from a 16.39% partnership interest in Online Game Revolution Fund
	No.&nbsp;1. We recorded Won 18&nbsp;million as equity loss of the partnership of Online Game Revolution Fund No.1 in 2013. On December&nbsp;31, 2010, the term of the partnership of Online Game Revolution Fund No.&nbsp;1 expired and its liquidation
	was completed in June 2013, which resulted in Online Game Revolution Fund No.&nbsp;1 ceasing to be our equity method investee.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	77
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage78"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D64640D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-controlling
</FONT>
	interest
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-controlling
</FONT>
	interest represents the net loss from NeoCyon, our
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	96.11%-held
</FONT>
	subsidiary and Gravity Games, our
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	85.5%-held
</FONT>
	subsidiary, attributable to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	third-party
</FONT>
	minority interest holders. We acquired
	96.11% of the voting equity of NeoCyon in 2005. We acquired 50.83% of the voting equity of Gravity Games in 2010 and increased our ownership in Gravity Games to 85.5% in August 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Net loss attributable to parent company
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As a result of the foregoing, we recorded a net loss attributable to parent company of Won&nbsp;20,907 million in 2014 compared
	to a net loss attributable to parent company of Won&nbsp;18,588 million in 2013.
</P>
</EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
